Award.AwardTitle: Patents, Cartographic Inventors, and a New Perspective for Map History

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Map historians and others who study the sources, processes, and outcomes of cartographic creativity traditionally have looked to maps and other manifestations of geographic information that have been copyrighted or presented in literature that can be catalogued. Far less common has been the use of patents to record inventions that have changed the ways in which maps are produced and portrayed. This project will analyze the role of the patents system in stimulating and recording cartographic creativity. The investigators will examine inventors as well as inventions, and it will focus on the technological, social, and intellectual context in which new map products and new techniques for making or using maps were deemed sufficiently original and non-obvious to warrant patent protection. The project will provide a complementary perspective to the literature dominated by academic and government cartographers. The project will yield new information and insights about those forms of cartographic innovation that have been patented. Project outcomes will include a biographical directory of cartographic inventors and their patents that the investigator and others can use to explore the personal and social motives of cartographic innovators, their contacts with other inventors, and the temporal context and impact of their inventions. The project therefore will stimulate fundamental thinking in map history, the history of sciences, geographer, and other scholarly fields. Another outcome of the project is expected to be a book accessible to lay readers examining this understudied aspect of creativity and innovation. The project will provide education and training experience for a graduate student. Data gathered during the conduct of the project will be deposited with the Geography and Map Division of the U.S. Library of Congress and other collections that will assist in the online dissemination of these data.

The project will expand upon two pilot studies. One pilot examined the diverse types of map-related U.S. patents awarded between 1840 and 2012 that were classified as "Printed matter--map" or "Printed matter--indexed maps." The other pilot studied the education, employment, and residential histories of two inventors and their efforts to exploit their patents. During the conduct of this project, the investigators will broaden the database to include other arenas of cartographic creativity, in particular map-related inventions assigned to the "Education and Demonstration" category. The principal research approach to be used in the conduct of this project is examination of "Big Microdata," a collective term for newspaper, bibliographic, and patents databases as well as individual-level archival population records like those provided online by Ancestry.com and Familysearch.org, which integrate information from city directories, pre-1950 Census schedules, and the diverse vital and public records used by genealogical researchers. In addition to broadening the scope of historical scholarship about mapping to include the systematic analysis of many little-known innovators, the investigators will provide an evidence-based critique of the concepts of utility, novelty, and patentability; the effectiveness of the patents system in maintaining standards of originality and non-obviousness. They also will examine the value of a monopoly right in stimulating creative endeavors, and they will explore information flows among inventors and the Theory of Multiples, whereby discoveries by two or more innovators suggest that many inventions might be seen, in retrospect, as an inevitable consequence of need or related technology. As a final part of this project, the investigators will evaluate the usefulness and limitations of Big Microdata as a research tool, and they will assess triangulation strategies for coping with transcription and coding errors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Map-related patents issued by the United States Patent Office from 1840 to around 2012 reflect the Congress's effort to encourage invention by creating an intellectual property right. Collectively, these patents constitute a systematic survey of technological accomplishment.

Case files from the National Archives contain valuable insights to the Patent Office's role in a "parallel literature" that complemented the traditional scientific-technical literature by providing systematic vetting, broad dissemination, and a durable record of personal achievement. Patents were vetted by patent examiners, who served as editors and referees. Pointedly adversarial at times, they diligently rejected claims previously awarded to someone else or rendered unacceptable because a once innovative idea had become "old" or "obvious." By contrast, the patent attorney, who represented the inventor, not only promoted linguistic clarity but often played the role of ghost-writer. Patents were published documents, with titles, numbers, and publication dates that could be cited by other inventors or listed in an inventor's curriculum vitae. The term "parallel literature" is particularly appropriate because there was very little cross-citation: articles in the scientific - technical - academic literature rarely cited patents, and when a patent cited an earlier publication, it was almost always another patent. That most cartographic inventions were never marketed suggests that for many inventors, fame was more important than fortune.

This notion of parallel literatures is consistent with the observation that map historians have largely ignored map-related patents: in Volume Six of the History of Cartography the entry on "Intellectual Property" addresses patents in only three of its 41 paragraphs, and contains only 18 instances of the word patent, in contrast to 84 instances of copyright. Moreover, in the entire million-word volume only five of the 5,115 references are to a specific patent.

Perhaps patented map-related inventions were too mundane for scholars focused on wars and national territory and other issues more interesting than quotidian maps like the "Transfer Ticket" map (US Patent 1,201,605, filed March 3, 1913, and issued October 17, 1917.) devised to discourage "looping" by streetcar riders who wanted to travel downtown and back without paying a second fare.

By way of disclosure, this project largely ignored the complications of digital cartography and the late twentieth century's more assertive corporate actors, who fostered preemptive patenting and enabled the patent troll. Nor did it address surveying and photogrammetric instruments, which seem well covered by historians of technology.

Basic data came from patents filtered by the US Patent Classification System still in effect a half-dozen years ago, and in particular the class/subclass categories "Printed Matter: Map" and "Printed Matter: Indexed Map," which provided a non-redundant dataset of 304 patents.

Various time-series graphs based on the "filed" dates of individual patents, not their "issued" dates, detected noteworthy temporal trends, in particular an irregularity related to major events in the late nineteenth and twentieth centuries, including the so-called Third Industrial Revolution, which reflects fundamental economic change inspired by new communication technologies that emerged after World War Two. This irregularity also reflects the weak statistical relationship between map patents and patents in general: the period 1880 to 2012 yielded a correlation coefficient of only 0.16, and a five-year running average raised this to only 0.26.

Examination of temporal trends for specific types of patented maps produced finding consistent with the "Theory of Multiples" famously endorsed in a 1922 paper by political scientists William Ogburn and Dorothy Thomas, who found that multiple, seemingly independent inventions or discoveries suggests that new, widely shared situations or perceptions can trigger an invention or discovery. This theory is consistent with a concentration in the first quarter of the twentieth century of map-related inventions that address land navigation. Improved road maps and signage undermined the market for these inventions, which were expensive and imprecise. Another disaggregation of the data reveals a concentration in the final quarter of the century of patents related to map folding, either for innovative folds per se or for innovations that include folding. These inventions are related to the advent of machinery able to manufacture Falk folds, pop-up maps, and Z-cards, all of which made paper maps more conveniently accessible to travelers.

The project's two principal products are the books Patents and Cartographic Inventions: A New Perspective for Map History, published in 2017 by Palgrave Macmillan in its Studies in the History of Science and Technology series, and A Directory of Cartographic Inventors: Clever People Awarded a US Patent for a Map-Related Device or Method, published in 2018 through Amazon. Patents and Cartographic Inventions has seven chapters: an introduction that examines connections between mapping and the patents system, and thematic chapters that look at georeferencing, navigation, map folding, map projections, globes, and pre-digital electronic cartography. The Directory, prepared with Syracuse University students, has short biographies for 32 inventors and single-paragraph capsule bios for 24 more.
